title: Asking about the location of things (Part 2): Advanced location questions and directions

title.english: Asking 'How do I get to...?' (كيفاش نوصل لـ...؟)

content.text: This is a common and very useful phrase when you need directions to a specific place. It literally means 'How do I arrive at...?'.

examples.english: How do I get to the station?
How do I get to the airport?

content.text: These are essential verbs for giving and receiving directions. 'سير' means 'go' and 'دور' means 'turn'. They are often used in the imperative form.

examples.english: Go straight.
Turn right.

content.text: When someone tells you to go straight, they will often use 'نيشان' or sometimes 'طوالى'. Both are widely understood.

examples.english: Go straight until the corner.
Keep going straight.

sentence.english: How do I get to the post office?

steps.question: Which phrase means 'How do I get to the hospital?'
steps.explanation: «كيفاش نوصل لـ» is used to ask for directions to a place.

title.english: Turning Left and Right (على اليسار / على اليمين)

content.text: To specify the direction of a turn, you'll use 'على اليسار' for left and 'على اليمين' for right.

examples.arabic: دور على اليمين من بعد الضو الأحمر.
examples.english: Turn right after the traffic light.
examples.transliteration: Dor 'ala l-yamin men ba'd eddḅaw el ahmar.

examples.english: From here turn left.

content.text: These adjectives describe distance. 'قريب' means near/close and 'بعيد' means far. They can be used with 'من' (men - from). Note the feminine forms: قريبة (qriba) and بعيدة (b'ida).

examples.english: Is the restaurant near here?
examples.transliteration: Wash el mat'am qrib men hna?

examples.english: The station is very far.

title.english: Asking About Distance (واش بعيد؟ / شحال بعيد؟)

content.text: You can inquire about the distance of a place by asking 'واش بعيد؟' (Is it far?) or 'شحال بعيد؟' (How far is it?).

examples.english: Is the post office far from here?
examples.transliteration: Wash el bosta b'ida men hna?

examples.english: How far is the hospital?

sentence.english: The mosque is near the market.

sentence.arabic: دور على اليسار عند الضو الأحمر.
sentence.english: Turn left at the traffic light.

steps.question: Complete the sentence: 'Is the restaurant ___ from here?' (near)

hint.transliteration: Wash el mat'am qrib men hna?

steps.question: How would you ask 'How far is the school?'
steps.explanation: «شحال بعيدة؟» is used to ask 'How far is it?'. Note the feminine form for 'المدرسة'.

title.english: Relative Locations: In Front Of, Behind (قدام / ورا)

content.text: These prepositions are crucial for describing objects' positions relative to others. 'قدام' means in front of, and 'ورا' means behind.

examples.english: The bank is in front of the mosque.
The car is behind the tree.

title.english: Relative Locations: Next To, Beside (جنب / حدا)

content.text: To say something is next to or beside another, you can use 'جنب' or 'حدا'. Both are common in Darija.

examples.english: The palace is next to the sea.
The cafe is next to the pharmacy.

title.english: Passing By / Going Through (دوز على / عبر)

content.text: When giving directions, you might need to say 'pass by' a certain landmark or 'go through' an area. 'دوز على' means pass by, and 'عبر' means cross/go through.

examples.english: Pass by the bakery.
Pass through the market.

sentence.english: The hospital is in front of the station.
The pharmacy is next to the post office.

steps.question: Complete the sentence: 'The cafe is ___ the bakery.' (next to)
How would you tell someone to 'Pass by the market'?
steps.explanation: «دوز على» is the phrase for 'pass by'.

title.english: At the Corner / At the Roundabout (فالقنت / فالروبوان)

content.text: These phrases are very useful for navigation in cities. 'فالقنت' means 'at the corner', and 'فالروبوان' means 'at the roundabout'.

examples.english: The library is at the corner of the street.
examples.transliteration: El maktaba fel qent dyal esh-shari'.

examples.english: Turn left at the first roundabout.
examples.transliteration: Dor 'ala l-yasar fel roubwan el awwel.

title.english: The Best Way / The Easiest Way (أحسن طريق / أسهل طريق)

content.text: When you want to ask for the most convenient route, you can use 'أحسن طريق' (best way) or 'أسهل طريق' (easiest way).

examples.arabic: أشنو هي أحسن طريق لـ المركز؟
examples.english: What is the best way to the center?
examples.transliteration: Ashnu hiya aHsen triq l-el markaz?

examples.english: Show me the easiest way.

title.english: Understanding Traffic Lights (الضو الأحمر / إشارة المرور)

content.text: Traffic lights are important landmarks. 'الضو الأحمر' (eddaw el ahmar) literally means 'the red light', and it's commonly used. 'إشارة المرور' (isharat el morour) is the more formal term.

examples.english: Stop at the traffic light.

examples.arabic: من بعد إشارة المرور، دور يمين.
examples.english: After the traffic light, turn right.
examples.transliteration: Men ba'd isharat el morour, dor yamin.

sentence.english: The salon is at the corner of the street.

sentence.arabic: أشنو هي أسهل طريق لـ المقهى؟
sentence.english: What is the easiest way to the cafe?
sentence.transliteration: Ashnu hiya ashal triq l-el maqha?

steps.question: Complete the sentence: 'What is the ___ way to the museum?' (best)

hint.transliteration: Ashnu hiya aHsen triq l-el matHaf?
hint.arabic: أشنو هي أحسن طريق لـ المتحف؟

steps.question: What is the common Darija term for 'traffic light'?
steps.explanation: «الضو الأحمر» literally means 'the red light' and is commonly used for traffic lights.

title.english: Combining Directions: 'Go straight, then turn...' (سير نيشان، ومن بعد دور...)

content.text: You'll often need to give multiple directions in sequence. Use 'ومن بعد' (and then/after that) to link instructions.

examples.arabic: سير نيشان، ومن بعد دور على اليمين.
examples.english: Go straight, and then turn right.
examples.transliteration: Sir nishan, w men ba'd dor 'ala l-yamin.

examples.arabic: دوز على البوسطة، ومن بعد دور على اليسار.
examples.english: Pass by the post office, and then turn left.
examples.transliteration: Douz 'ala l-bosta, w men ba'd dor 'ala l-yasar.

title.english: Asking for Specific Landmarks (واش كاين شي معلمة؟)

content.text: When you're lost or trying to clarify directions, you might ask 'واش كاين شي معلمة قريبة؟' (Is there any nearby landmark?) or 'أشنو كاين تماك؟' (What is there over there?).

examples.arabic: واش كاين شي فندق قريب من هنا؟
examples.english: Is there any hotel near here?
examples.transliteration: Wash kayn shi fondeq qrib men hna?

examples.english: What is next to this place?
examples.transliteration: Ashnu kayn Hda had el blasa?

content.text: It's good practice to confirm understanding or ask someone to repeat directions. 'واش فهمتي؟' (Did you understand? - masculine) / 'واش فهمتِ؟' (Did you understand? - feminine) and 'عاود عفاك' (Repeat please) are useful.

examples.arabic: سير نيشان، ومن بعد دور على اليمين. واش فهمتي؟
examples.english: Go straight, then turn right. Did you understand?
examples.transliteration: Sir nishan, w men ba'd dor 'ala l-yamin. Wash fhemtî?

examples.english: Repeat please, I didn't hear well.

sentence.arabic: سير نيشان، ومن بعد دوز على المكتبة.
sentence.english: Go straight, and then pass by the library.
sentence.transliteration: Sir nishan, w men ba'd douz 'ala l-maktaba.

sentence.arabic: واش كاين شي مقهى حدا المركز؟
sentence.english: Is there any cafe next to the center?
sentence.transliteration: Wash kayn shi maqha Hda l-markaz?

sentence.arabic: عاود عفاك كيفاش نوصل لـ المسجد؟
sentence.english: Repeat please, how do I get to the mosque?

steps.question: Which phrase is used to link sequential directions, meaning 'and then'?
steps.explanation: «من بعد» means 'after' or 'and then' in this context.

steps.question: Complete the question: 'Is there any ___ near here?' (landmark)

hint.transliteration: Wash kayn shi ma'lama qriba men hna?
hint.arabic: واش كاين شي معلمة قريبة من هنا؟

steps.question: How do you ask 'Did you understand?' (to a male)?
steps.explanation: «واش فهمتي؟» is used to ask a male 'Did you understand?'.
